And we are not prepared to continue at those levels of sales support our business in the course of this year. So that's why we don't think that the fourth quarter is really something you can put as a basis for your assumptions, how we will develop our business in the course of this year.
Okay, Frank Biller and John Buckland [MAN Securities], yes.

Yes, Frank Biller from LBBW. Just coming back on your leasing business again, am I right in this assumption that your provisions are also going for the leasing fleet coming back in 2010? I misheard some sort of things, just the calculation if leasing residual values, car residual values are staying as we are today, is there an additional provision coming in the course of this year for 2010 leasing fleet? And the other thing is in credit default rates here, additional provisioning in 2009, what default rates you are calculating or what's the magnitude of your provisions and are you calculating this default rate of 2% roughly or is it lower?

Now, coming back to provisions, clearly, as I said, the provisions are allocated for the whole portfolio. So also for contracts that will mature in 2010 and 2011. So in order to give you a clue, just take a – I mean it's different from market to market, just to give you an example of the biggest market, the leasing market, U.S. We calculated the provisions for 2009 based on the results, on the losses we had to consider at the end of 2008, so both November and December numbers. And they were extraordinarily high. So this is the basis for the provision calculation for this year. Now for 2010, we are calculating certain improvement on the residual values, but it's still extraordinary high. And if you look at the long-term average, I would say, it's three times higher than the long-term average. And now if you look at 2011, there we see two effects that we had to take into consideration. First is, we lowered our leasing – contractual lease prices in – the contractual residual values in the leasing contracts we had in 2008, so we now have a lower basis and this is another step forward in order to manage the risk there. Second with the shift from leasing to financing the maturities, the volume in 2011 will go down significantly. And it will be a mid two-digit number. So both effects should help us really to stabilize the business. And I mean nobody knows how this price will move forward, but with everything we can judge now, we think it should be sufficient, it should be the right order of magnitude.
So, I think we have time for two more questions, John and then Philippe.

Thank you. You seem very confident about your profitability target 2012 and there's been debate about what the volume will be when you come to that year. But you also said you're very confident that raw material costs will be significantly more than you had previously planned. Are you – can you say with some certainty that you will meet these 2012 profitability targets, irrespective of what the volume is going to be? I mean obviously, you can't be completely independent, but can you categorize how – what is the minimum volume? Can you run at current production levels with the new models, with the raw material cost and meet those targets? I mean is that something that's been in your back pocket there? And the other – going back to this – the provisions and you've made – in the fourth quarter did you make a change in policy, In other words, more conservative compared to what you did for 2008 because the words that you're using now about we can't rule out more provisions is basically what you'd said at the beginning of 2008. In every quarter, you made another provision and you got the – the biggest one was at the end of the year. So have you made a real change to, say, we've looked at everything, we've looked forward sufficiently such that we are in a position to say unless there's an absolute catastrophe, there won't be more of this drip-drip on the residual value or the loan loss as well. And then on the – just on the final quick question on the production, we are in the middle of March. You must know what your production is going to be for the full first quarter of this year. How does the production volume look compared to the fourth quarter? Can you actually give us a number of production volumes for the first quarter or close to. Thanks.
Okay, thank you very much, John. Norbert Reithofer?

I mean, first let me start in the year 2008 again, only to explain to you why we are confident for the year 2012. I mean if you see additional – let me say costs for residual values for, that we had to, for our personnel reductions what we needed, residual values, credit loss is two billion. As we all know in the meantime, head count reduction 0.5 million. Then if you add on top 0.6 million for higher raw material prices and currency effects in the year 2008, then you are far over three billion. And if you're still able as a company to make an EBIT of more than 900 million, then you were able to make progress on the cost side definitely. So are we well on track on the cost side? Yes, we – in my opinion, we are very well on track on the cost side. And that gives us confidence that we have to hold cost side under control.

And let me say, we launched, as I mentioned, the new 1 Series, the new 3 Series products starting in the year 2011. 5 Series will come in the year 2010, and we will have launch, launch after launch and you can trust us. We turned around every screw, we calculated component for component, we calculated sub-assembly for sub-assembly. Different compared to the past, totally different with, let me say, a total cost focus. That means these products will move us further if it comes through the cost structures of our company. So that is my first answer. Why we are confident? And that, as I said, we have 100% under our control. We cannot have excuses. That is what we can influence 100%.

So let me now come again to the year 2012 from a volume point of view. I mean, I said we cannot achieve 1.8 million cars anymore. And I said, yes, it can be 100,000 units less. I don't know yet the real figures because we don't know what will happen until the year 2012. And I would be a very rich man if I would know what will happen in the year 2012 now because then I would buy the right shares. So that means we don't know yet what will be the volume, but I'm very confident that we can achieve between 1.6 and 1.7 million cars. So, and – but I don't know, to be honest. So will we focus on our profit targets? Yes, because from a cost structure point of view, we should be able to achieve it even if we have only a volume of 1.6 million cars because what we have to do in our company, we have to lower our breakeven in any case. And Mr. Eichiner said the current situation is a very good fitness training for our company. I mean if you have volume drops of 25%, you can have no better fitness program.
Okay, Friedrich Eichiner.

Well, your question about the provisions, are they sufficient, do we have to expect another hit, yes or no? I mean, basically I have to say we cannot rule out now that there will be no further risk on horizon. And nobody can, because this would mean, I don't know exactly how these crisis will come to an end and how it would proceed into the future. So I don't know it. But what I can say it that we really had covered all foreseeable risks from the day's perspective. That's what we really tried to do. If for example, a crisis is taking longer or it's going even deeper as levels we see today, I mean this could then give a different picture. But from today's perspective, I said we've done everything to cover foreseeable risk and that is now in the books. If you look at the actual development and what it says today, I mean I explained what we see in the U.S., the U.S. development on residual value losses is supporting our view today, that's what I can say. So with January and February, I mean it's online or even better than we've planned. So that is positive, but we don't know how the crisis will proceed. And if you go to – if you look at the credit risks, now if there is another bank going down and things are getting worse, then dealers have more trouble than we anticipated, then I mean you have further risks. That's all I can say at that point in time.

But can you not say whether you looked more critically in the fourth quarter than you did in the previous quarters because in 2008, you – each quarter they said, oh, we've looked at it, this is the view we have today. But the view is wrong. And you can have two ways. You can look at it what the market is now, and say I make decisions on what market is now or you can say we make a much more conservative assumption about the future, let's say, it continues to go down as the rate it's been going down, and we project that forward, and we make the provisions on that basis, which is completely different philosophy, and then therefore you have a sort of cushion for the future.
Yes.
And I don't get the impression you got a cushion for the future.
John, we understand it, yes.

Well, I mean I explained that of course. We took our learnings out of the development on residual value losses side over the course of autumn last year. That was very clear, and it goes into our back testing, it goes into our risk management, that is all taken into consideration. And I already explained, for example, that we brought the contractual residual values down now by a significant step is another sign that we are more conservative in this business. And the second thing is that, as I explained already, that we shifted from the leasing business to the financing business and that is still something that we are now following up this year.

So, we try to come to a better balance in '09, '10 with the new contracts for leasing and loan in order to take some risk out of the business. And the third thing is that we try to improve our processes and especially our used car channels. So for example in U.S., U.S. dealers were not prepared to market used cars in – to the certain extent that was – usually those were independent used car dealers doing though. Now we are building up this channel even strongly in order to stabilize our used car values as well. So there's a lot going on now in order to really come to a structurally better business model in the area of Financial Services.
So, we are on time; it's 12 o'clock. Last question, Philippe.

Thank you. I'll try to be quick. And sorry to go back to this issue of the FinCo, but it's on everybody's mind I think. To help us understand some of these issues, I think we've seen your financing costs go up gradually, which is fine. We see that in the market, you're trying to re-price your leasing offers, your loans and it's not as easy as you'd like it to be of course, keep on lose too many customers. But my question there is, at what point do you get to a situation if you can no longer increase the interest rate you charge your customers and your financing costs continue to increase on a trend we've seen recently, at what point you'll start operating the FinCo on negative spreads? That's my first question.

The second question would be on this issue of re-capitalization of FinCo, which is on everybody's mind, and I'm sure you're going to have meetings with Moody's, S&P, etcetera over the next few weeks. I'm looking at your new segmentation and how different it is, etcetera. Can you give us an idea of what kind of metric the rating agency will look at to determine that you need to put more equity in the FinCo? I think I'm comfortable you can do it internally, but what kind of leverage ratio, what kind of indicators do you need to satisfy the rating agencies or will they either touch you or they will force you or require that you put more equity in the FinCo? If you can help us understand, that will be great.

Coming back to the last question, I mean we are in discussion with the rating agencies. And I think it's not so much the equity questions that we have to answer. I mean they are looking at our cash flow, they are looking at our liquidity position, and of course at our earnings and ratios. And as we can, could demonstrate so far, we have, besides the reduction in profits, we have some good news on the liquidity side that we can offer. If it's enough, we don't know. We are in the middle of the process. And on the other side, there is a negative trend in the industry; and this is something that have to – that we have to consider as well. So, we work with them, and there's – we don't know the outcome yet at that point in time.

Now the question again about the leasing and how we – and the spreads, we have to see two points. I think all the car manufacturers who compete in the market have the same situation now. Right? They'll have to rebalance their – the leasing business. I cannot see that BMW is the only one who is struggling with leasing. Everybody does, but some aren't showing it. They have it in other cost positions. You don't see the risk provision that we've clearly made transparent, and we have to come to the right approach there. We are not prepared to really sort of get away from our arm's length principle, but we have – of course we have tactical spendings in our sales where our sales people are trying to balance their offers against those of the competition. Then you have maybe a discussion in cost of sales on the pricing side, but we are not going away from our arm's length principle when it comes down to financing of Financial Services.

Okay. Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen for the discussion. I think it was a good discussion about more than 70 minutes. And our reporting experts, Dr. Wittig and Mr. Engewald, will be available during lunch and will be more than happy to walk you through the accounts and especially through the net interest-bearing assets of the Auto segment and also Mr. Eichiner and Mr. Reithofer will be present. Thank you very much. I think we meet us for launch. Thank you.
